content: The Secretary is restricted from implementing revenue-raising measures recommended by the Commission if a joint resolution disapproving the recommendations is enacted within a 45-day period. This provision excludes days when Congress is adjourned for more than 3 days. The Secretary of the Treasury's Creative Revenues Commission is established with 11 members appointed by the Secretary, tasked with recommending revenue-raising measures by December 31, 1997. The Creative Revenues Commission is tasked with recommending revenue-raising measures by reviewing various forms of taxation in different countries to balance the Federal tax burden between corporations and individuals. The Commission will transmit the report to the Secretary and the Committees on Ways and Means and Finance. The Creative Revenues Commission will consist of members who serve without compensation, except for possible travel expenses. The Creative Revenues Commission will be provided with necessary administrative support and expenses will be paid from available funds. The professional staff composition will have limitations, and the Commission will brief the Secretary on its plan of action once operational. The report transmitted under subsection (c)(1) must include a revenue raising measure recommendation approved by a majority of the Commission members. SEC. 6. REPORTS. The Secretary of the Treasury must provide Congress with a schedule of revenue-raising measures, total expenditures, cost savings or increases, and estimates of tax changes for individual and corporate taxpayers in the annual budget request. The Secretary of the Treasury must provide Congress with a schedule of revenue-raising measures, total expenditures, cost savings or increases, and estimates of tax changes for individual and corporate taxpayers in the annual budget request, including details on the time period for generating such increases or decreases. SEC. 7. FUNDING. The Department of the Treasury Revenue Reform Account is established in the Treasury of the United States, administered by the Secretary as a single account. Funds authorized and appropriated for fiscal year 1999 and beyond, as well as funds transferred with approval from the Secretary, are deposited into the Account. The Secretary may use funds in the Account for implementing revenue raising measures under this Act. Annual reports on deposits, expenditures, and other expenses must be submitted to Congress. Unobligated funds in the Account after September 30, 2002, will be held until transferred by law. The Secretary must submit a final report to Congress by November 30, 2002, detailing all funds deposited, expended, and remaining in the Account. SEC. 8. Congressional consideration of regulatory reforms recommended in commission report. The term "joint resolution" refers to a resolution introduced before March 15, 1998, without a preamble, disapproving recommendations of the Creative Revenues Commission. Resolutions introduced in the House of Representatives are referred to the Committee on Ways and Means. The House Committee on Ways and Means handles resolutions introduced in the House, while the Senate Committee on Finance deals with resolutions introduced in the Senate. SEC. 9. CONGRESSIONAL CONSIDERATION OF NON-REGULATORY REFORMS RECOMMENDED IN COMMISSION REPORT. The Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate must introduce legislation by March 14, 1998, to implement non-regulatory reforms recommended in the report. Legislation introduced in the House goes to the Committee on Ways and Means, and in the Senate to the Committee on Finance. If reform legislation is not reported by a committee before March 15, 1998, the committee will be discharged from further consideration, and the legislation will be placed on the House calendar. After the committee reports or is discharged, any Member can move to proceed with the legislation for consideration. The motion for reform legislation is highly privileged in the House of Representatives and privileged in the Senate. It is not debatable, amendable, or subject to reconsideration. If agreed to, the respective House will immediately proceed to consider the legislation without any interruptions. Reform legislation in the House of Representatives and Senate is highly privileged, not debatable, amendable, or subject to reconsideration. Once agreed to, the respective House will immediately proceed to consider the legislation without interruptions. Debate on the legislation is limited to 10 hours, divided equally between those in favor and those opposing, with no amendments allowed. Additional motions to limit debate, postpone, proceed to other business, or reconsider the vote are not in order. Reform legislation in the House and Senate is privileged, not debatable, amendable, or subject to reconsideration. After debate, a single quorum call may be requested, followed by a vote on final passage. Appeals on rules application are decided without debate. If one House receives reform legislation from the other, specific procedures apply. The reform legislation in the House and Senate is privileged and follows specific procedures if received from the other House. Such legislation cannot be referred to a committee and must be voted on for final passage. Once the reform legislation is disposed of, it cannot be considered again. The reform legislation in the House and Senate follows specific procedures if received from the other House. It is deemed a part of the rules of each House and can supersede other rules only to the extent inconsistent with such rules. Each House has the constitutional right to change the rules relating to the procedure at any time. SEC. 11. DEFINITIONS. For purposes of this Act, the term "Account" refers to the Department of the Treasury Revenue Reform Account. The term "appropriate committees of Congress" includes specific committees in the House and Senate. The "Creative Revenues Commission" or "Commission" is the Secretary of the Treasury's Creative Revenues Commission. "Reform legislation" refers to resolutions or legislation described in specific sections. A "revenue raising measure" is also defined within the Act. (5) Revenue raising measure refers to a proposal to amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, implement regulatory changes, or any other proposal to raise revenue for the Federal Government. (6) Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Treasury.
